A lateral pharyngeal abscess (parapharyngeal abscess) is an infection of the lateral pharyngeal space that is contiguous with the retropharyngeal space. In addition to GABHS, Staphylococcus aureus and oropharyngeal anaerobic organisms may be involved. Epiglottitis (supraglottitis), a bacterial infection of the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, arytenoid soft tissue, and uvula, most commonly was caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b before the H. influenzae type b vaccine. Thermal epiglottitis may occur from hot foods or liquids or from smoking freebase cocaine. Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, a viral infection of the upper airway, has a similar clinical presentation to epiglottitis.

Physiologic adenotonsillar hyperplasia refers to the fact that tonsils and adenoids are normally larger in children than in adults. Without symptoms of infection or obstruction, adenotonsillar size has no medical significance. Adenotonsillar hypertrophy may occur acutely with infection or may be chronic, resulting in pathologically enlarged tonsils that cause obstruction of airflow and result in an obstructive sleep disorder. Obstructive sleep apnea or obstructive sleep apnea syndrome has a prevalence of approximately 2% and occurs most commonly in children 2 to 5 years old (see the CD-ROM and Chapters 63 and 251).

Pharyngeal tumors in children are uncommon. Benign tumors of the oropharynx and hypopharynx include juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, hamartomas, hemangiomas, and neurofibromas. The most common malignant tumors of this region are lymphoma and rhabdomyosarcoma.

Trauma to the pharynx, most often from foreign objects, such as pencils, sticks, or toys, may cause injuries such as contusions, lacerations, and penetration of the pharyngeal structures. Burns and caustics also may cause trauma to the pharynx.

Sore throat accounts for approximately 5% of all pediatric visits, is less common in children younger than 1 year old, and peaks between 5 and 8 years of age. Viral pharyngitis occurs most commonly in the summer and fall. Bacterial pharyngitis occurs most frequently in the winter and spring and is uncommon in children younger than 3 years old. Approximately 15% of cases of pharyngitis in school-age children are caused by GABHS.

Typically, viral pharyngitis follows inhalation of airborne droplets or self-inoculation of organisms into the nasal mucosa or conjunctiva and viral invasion of the respiratory epithelium. Pain results from the effect of inflammatory mediators on vascular permeability and on pain nerve endings. Bacterial organisms, in particular GABHS, directly invade the mucous membranes. Streptolysin O and hyaluronidase, enzymes produced by GABHS, facilitate the local spread of infection.

Viruses are the most common cause of nasopharyngitis and pharyngitis in children (Table 64 -1). Rhinovirus typically is associated with upper respiratory symptoms, such as cough and rhinorrhea. Adenovirus often causes an exudative pharyngitis, usually in children younger than 3 years old. Parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus, and influenza virus cause sore throat and croup. Coxsackievirus and echovirus (enteroviruses) are the usual cause of herpangina, sore throat that may be associated with high fever, irritability, and refusal to eat or drink leading to dehydration. Enteroviral infections are most common in the late spring, summer, and early fall. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) usually is associated with tonsillar exudate and is often difficult to distinguish from GABHS infection.

The most common cause of bacterial pharyngitis in children (usually >3 years old) is GABHS. Other bacteria that cause pharyngitis are group C and G β-hemolytic streptococci and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Arcanobacterium haemolyticum, an organism that infects mostly adolescents and young adults, has findings similar to GABHS infection. Diphtheria is an uncommon cause of pharyngitis in immunized children.

Chlamydia species probably cause pharyngitis. Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseriae gonorrhoeae may be sexually transmitted causes of pharyngitis, but are uncommon. The presence of these organisms in children raises a high suspicion of sexual abuse. M. pneumoniae causes mild pharyngitis, but usually is associated with lower respiratory infections. If there has been contact with wild animals, tularemia should be considered. Candida pharyngitis is uncommon but may occur in children who are immunocompromised or whose throat flora has been changed from the use of antibiotics.

Peritonsillar abscess, the most common infection in deep head and neck tissue, occurs most frequently in older children, adolescents, and young adults. Almost all patients with this disorder have a history of tonsillitis, most often bacterial or EBV, which then spreads to the surrounding tissue causing a peritonsillar cellulitis. If the cellulitis does not resolve spontaneously or with treatment, a peritonsillar abscess develops.

Retropharyngeal abscess occurs most frequently in younger children (usually <6 years old). A probable mechanism is development of a retropharyngeal abscess after suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes lying on either side of the retropharyngeal space. These nodes, which markedly diminish in size by 6 years of age, drain the pharynx, sinuses, teeth, and other oral structures. Trauma to the posterior pharynx from foreign objects, a common injury in small children, is frequently the cause of retropharyngeal abscess. Lateral pharyngeal abscesses, also known as parapharyngeal abscesses, are uncommon. They may occur from penetrating trauma or from extension of infection from another part of the mouth or pharynx, such as from a peritonsillar abscess.
Epiglottitis is a cause of severe throat pain. It is a lifethreatening disorder that causes rapid airway obstruction and death if untreated (see the CD-ROM and Chapters 110 and 111).

Adenotonsillar hypertrophy is the most common pharyngeal cause of obstructive sleep disorders in children. The narrowing of the pharyngeal airway may be caused by these enlarged structures or, in some patients, by partial or total collapse of the pharynx from decreased muscular tone during sleep.

Trauma to the pharynx may be physical, chemical, or thermal. Physical trauma follows penetration of the soft palate into the pharynx or direct injury to the pharynx by a foreign object causing contusions, punctures, and lacerations. Objects such as pencils, toys, toothbrushes, straws, and sticks are often in the mouths of children when they fall, causing the object to injure the pharynx. Occasionally a child may fall with an open mouth onto an object causing pharyngeal injury. Trauma from automobiles, bicycles, scooters, roller skates, and in-line skates may involve the pharynx and the larynx. Often these injuries cause significant bleeding, increased secretions, edema, and hematomas, leading to respiratory distress and airway compromise. Penetrating injuries from bullets, knives, and animal bites also may cause significant airway compromise. Acid or base ingestions (caustics) may cause pharyngeal, laryngeal, or esophageal injury. Bases such as lye or ammonia usually cause the most serious injuries, including airway compromise. Thermal trauma to the pharynx may occur from fire. More commonly, hot liquids and foods cause ulceration of the hard palate, but they also may cause thermal pharyngeal injury.

Pharyngitis presents with sore throat often accompanied by fever. The dilemma for most generalists is determining the cause of the symptoms-infectious or not, viral or bacterial? The history and physical examination provide important clues, although ultimately laboratory tests may be needed for the correct diagnosis.

Children with a sore throat associated with cough and rhinorrhea usually have a viral pharyngitis, whereas children with sudden onset of high fever; severe pharyngitis; red, enlarged tonsils with tonsillar exudate; headache; and cervical lymphadenopathy are more likely to have GABHS. Many experts recommend that a rapid antigen test or throat culture be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GABHS because the diagnosis cannot be made accurately on clinical grounds alone. Others believe that the presence of a constellation of physical findings can predict the probability of infection from GABHS (Table 64 -2). Depending on the practice of the generalist, this categorization may be used to develop an efficient diagnostic and treatment approach. Patients may be treated empirically without rapid antigen or throat culture testing (high-risk group [>65% probability]) or not treated and not tested (low-risk group [<15% probability]). Children in the moderate-risk group (15% to 65% probability) should be tested to determine whether they have GABHS infection. Other physical findings suggesting GABHS infection are petechiae on the soft palate ( Fig. 64 -2) and uvula; a red and inflamed uvula; a strawberry tongue; and Pastia's lines, which accompany the scarlatiniform rash of scarlet fever. Abdominal pain on history or physical examination is common with GABHS pharyngitis. Adolescents and young adults who have similar clinical findings, including a scarlatiniform rash, but without a strawberry tongue or palatal petechiae, may have pharyngitis secondary to A. haemolyticum.

Viral causes of pharyngitis may be suggested by association with the common cold (rhinoviruses and coronaviruses) and other clinical features. Adenovirus is characterized by high fever, exudative pharyngitis, and conjunctivitis (pharyngoconjunctival fever). Features of herpangina include 1-to 2-mm vesicles and subsequently larger ulcers on the anterior tonsillar pillars, soft palate, and pharynx ( Fig. 64-3 ). Herpangina usually is caused by enteroviruses (coxsackievirus and echovirus). Hand-foot-and-mouth disease, caused by coxsackievirus A 16 and enterovirus 71, is characterized by vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and sometimes other parts of the body, particularly the knees, buttocks, tongue, labial and buccal mucosa, and palate and

Pharyngitis also may occur secondary to herpes simplex virus (HSV), but vesicles and ulcers almost always are present anteriorly . Inflammation of the gingiva (herpes gingivostomatitis) distinguishes HSV from enteroviral infection. High fever is characteristic of these infections, but refusal to eat and drink from painful lesions is more common in HSV infection. Fever; swollen, red tonsils; tonsillar exudate; cervical lymphadenopathy; diffuse adenopathy; and palatal petechiae are characteristic findings of infectious mononucleosis. Distinguishing between GABHS infection and infectious mononucleosis (EBV) can be difficult. Fatigue and malaise preceding other symptoms are more characteristic of mononucleosis. Eyelid or periorbital edema, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and a maculopapular rash without the other clinical characteristics of scarlet fever suggest mononucleosis. Diphtheria is rare, but should be considered in unimmunized children with a pharyngeal and tonsillar grayish pseudomembranous exudate that bleeds when removal is attempted. Peritonsillar abscess usually presents after GABHS pharyngitis or injury to the posterior pharynx with significant pain on swallowing, trismus, and a muffled voice often called a "hot potato" voice. On physical examination, there is a characteristic "bulge" in the soft palate on the side of the affected tonsil, and the uvula is pushed to the opposite side of the pharynx (Fig. 64-6 ). Retropharyngeal abscess usually is preceded by pharyngitis or injury to the posterior pharynx. Children with this disorder usually have a high fever; appear toxic; often drool because of the pain associated with swallowing; and may have neck pain, torticollis, or meningismus. Bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall may be appreciated, and cervical adenitis may be present. A lateral pharyngeal abscess presents with clinical findings almost identical to findings of retropharyngeal abscess. Torticollis may be present from tenderness and swelling of the neck on the affected side. A good view of the oropharynx may reveal swelling of the lateral pharyngeal wall and displacement of the tonsil medially.

Epiglottitis typically presents with sudden onset of high fever in a child who is extremely anxious and toxic appearing. Children with epiglottitis have pain with swallowing, drool, are stridorous, and almost always assume a tripod position. Croup typically begins with upper respiratory symptoms followed by a barklike cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Children with croup are usually not ill appearing, swallow without difficulty, and do not drool. Croup is usually a self-limited illness that resolves over 2 to 3 days. Adenotonsillar hypertrophy is suggested by a history of mouth breathing, loud snoring, hyponasal voice, and sleep apnea. Physical examination may reveal adenoid facies (open mouth, dull appearance, dark discoloration under the eyes) and enlarged tonsils. The size of the adenoids is difficult to determine on examination, but enlargement may be presumed in a child with hyponasality, normal nasal mucosa, and no palatal abnormalities (e.g., a bifid uvula indicating a submucous cleft palate). The extent of tonsillar obstruction ( Fig. 64-7) is based on the percent of obstruction of the oropharynx between anterior pillars and is scored from 0 to 4+: 0, tonsils are in the fossa, without obstruction; 1+, less than 25% obstruction; 2+, less than 50% obstruction; 3+, less than 75% obstruction; and 4+, more than 75% obstruction (see the CD-ROM). The clinical diagnosis of obstructive sleep disorders, particularly obstructive sleep apnea, can be made with an historical account of a child's sleep pattern. The most common complaint is of snoring, usually associated with irregular breathing, paradoxical chest/abdomen movement, difficulty breathing, decreased or no airflow when attempting to breathe, sleeping in an unusual position, restlessness, frequent apneic episodes, and sometimes cyanosis. Videotaping of a child's sleep pattern by the parent may be helpful to the physician. Enuresis also may be a frequent nighttime complaint. Mouth breathing and hyponasal speech are common daytime symptoms. Poor school performance or aggressive or hyperactive behavior may be observed in children with sleep disorders. Daytime somnolence and obesity are much less common in children than in adults with these disorders. Failure to thrive is more commonly present.

Physical examination in children with a suspected obstructive sleep disorder should begin with an assessment of growth. The oropharyngeal examination often reveals adenoidal or tonsillar hypertrophy. Patients should be observed for mouth breathing and hyponasal speech. Craniofacial dysmorphology should be documented, particularly micrognathia, macroglossia, and maxillary hypoplasia. A complete cardiovascular examination may reveal findings of corpulmonale or resultant congestive heart failure. A complete neurologic and developmental examination may suggest a neurologic etiology.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas most commonly occur in prepubertal boys. Nasal obstruction and frequent episodes of epistaxis are early symptoms of this disorder. Significant posterior epistaxis, nasal speech, and soft and hard palate deformity may be appreciated as the tumor enlarges. Malignant tumors of the nasopharynx, most commonly rhabdomyosarcomas and carcinomas, also may present with nasal obstruction, posterior cervical adenopathy, and eustachian tube dysfunction. Cranial nerve involvement may occur as the tumor enlarges.

Tumors of the oropharynx and hypopharynx are uncommon. Benign tumors may present as an enlarging mass projecting from oropharyngeal or hypopharyngeal structures. Malignant tumors also present with a mass, often in the tonsil, but there may be cervical lymph node involvement, particularly the jugulodigastric node; dysphagia; snoring; or stridor. If the tonsil is involved, there may be an ulcerated or hemorrhagic mass present. Unilateral tonsillar enlargement should raise the suspicion of malignant tumor, particularly if there is rapid tonsillar enlargement, dysphagia, systemic symptoms, and cervical lymphadenopathy. If the tonsil appears abnormal, including a color difference from the other tonsil, or if there is persistent ulceration, an increased likelihood of malignancy exists, particularly lymphoma. Lymphoma also should be considered in children with rapid bilateral tonsillar enlargement. Symptoms of pharyngeal and laryngeal injury include dysphagia, odynophagia, and dysphonia. Crepitance in the neck may be present. Respiratory distress and stridor suggest airway obstruction and may require endotracheal intubation. Vascular injury should be considered with trauma to the posterior pharyngeal wall, persistent bleeding, or an enlarging hematoma. Parents should be asked to provide any suspected penetrating object to be examined for pieces that may have been broken off and been retained in the area of injury. With caustic ingestions, the type of product, the brand name, and quantity ingested should be determined. Drooling and refusal to eat or drink are common symptoms of caustic oropharyngeal burns. Physical examination should note the extent of injury and involvement of surrounding structures so that the appropriate imaging studies may be obtained and appropriate consultants notified.

Laboratory tests and imaging studies are often helpful in the diagnosis of pharyngeal disorders. Throat culture is the most reliable test for confirming the diagnosis of bacterial pharyngitis, particularly GABHS. The large number of children who are streptococcal carriers (15% to 20%) causes a high rate of false-positive throat cultures. The false-negative rate is approximately 10%. The throat culture is the gold standard by which other tests are judged. The greatest disadvantage of throat cultures is that results are not final for 1 to 2 days. Although rapid streptococcal antigen detection tests provide immediate results and are reliable when they are positive (approximately 95% specificity), they are less reliable when negative (approximately 80% to 90% sensitive). Because newer optical immunoassay and chemoluminescent DNA rapid streptococcal antigen tests are as sensitive as throat cultures, confirmatory culture no longer is recommended routinely (see the CD-ROM).

Determination of the precise cause of viral pharyngitis is rarely necessary. In unusual instances, when there is a treatable systemic infection, such as encephalitis caused by HSV, viral throat cultures and acute and convalescent titers may be helpful. Infectious mononucleosis is diagnosed best with a heterophil agglutination test, particularly in children older than 4 years of age and later in the course of illness. A white blood cell count with a predominance of lymphocytes or greater than 10% atypical lymphocytes supports the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis. Gonorrheal pharyngitis may be diagnosed by a positive culture on a Thayer-Martin plate. Tularemia may be diagnosed with a serum agglutination test, and confirmatory diagnosis of diphtheria may be made by culture of the pseudomembrane or by fluorescent antibody technique.

Imaging studies are particularly useful for the diagnosis of deep infections of the pharyngeal space. Lateral soft tissue radiographs of the neck are helpful in patients suspected of having a retropharyngeal abscess and may be used as a screening study. If the lateral neck film suggests a retropharyngeal abscess or if there is a high degree of clinical suspicion for this diagnosis, computed tomography (CT) scan with contrast enhancement from the base of the cranium to the upper mediastinum usually is recommended for better delineation of the abscess and surrounding tissue. A CT scan also should be obtained if there is suspicion of a lateral pharyngeal abscess. Peritonsillar abscess is usually a clinical diagnosis, but in cases in which the diagnosis is not clear, CT scan is beneficial. The information obtained by CT is comparable to that of magnetic resonance imaging, and CT generally is more readily available and is less costly. Ultrasound examination of the head and neck for deep infection has not been shown to be as good an imaging study as CT. Chest radiographs or CT may be helpful if there is concern of extension of the infection into the mediastinum.

Epiglottitis usually can be diagnosed clinically. In cases in which there is suspicion of epiglottitis but the diagnosis is unlikely, a lateral neck x-ray may be helpful. A portable x-ray in the emergency department is preferable to sending the patient to radiology because of the potential of respiratory compromise.

All of these studies should be performed with the immediate availability of oxygen, bag-valve-mask ventilation, and endotracheal intubation. A physician should be present who is capable of performing endotracheal intubation if the patient has significant airway compromise during the study.

Children with adenotonsillar hypertrophy and obstructive sleep apnea disorders often are diagnosed clinically and do not need further diagnostic studies. In some cases, polysomnography, also known as a sleep study, is useful in confirming the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea, particularly when the history is unclear or when surgery may be more complex and of higher risk, such as in children with craniofacial anomalies.

Pharyngeal foreign bodies and subcutaneous air from trauma sometimes may be seen on lateral neck or chest x-ray. CT scan with contrast enhancement is the best imaging study for delineating laryngeal trauma. The extent of tumors of the pharynx is determined best with CT or magnetic resonance imaging.

The management of pharyngeal disorders is varied and depends on the etiology. Pharyngitis usually is viral in origin and may be treated symptomatically with analgesics, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, to relieve pain of pharyngitis and promote oral hydration. Parents should be instructed about monitoring fluid intake and the signs of dehydration. An older child may derive some relief from gargling with warm salt water or sucking on hard candy or mentholated throat lozenges.

If the pharyngitis is bacterial in origin, antibiotic treatment is indicated. GABHS is treated with penicillin. Evidence suggests that antibiotic treatment provides more rapid relief of symptoms, shortens the course of illness, and prevents suppurative complications and rheumatic fever. Patients who have suppurative complications, such as peritonsillar abscess; are toxic appearing; have scarlet fever; or have a past history of rheumatic fever should be treated with penicillin on the basis of clinical findings. Confirmation of infection by rapid streptococcus test or throat culture is unnecessary in these situations. If streptococcal pharyngitis is treated within 9 days of the initial symptoms, rheumatic fever can be prevented. Antibiotic therapy probably does not affect the development of glomerulonephritis. Antibiotics used for streptococcal pharyngitis are listed in Table 64 -3. Oral penicillin needs to be administered only two to three times per day. Patients should be advised that it is important to complete the full 10-day course, even if the child feels better after 2 to 3 days. Intramuscular penicillin should be administered when there are concerns about compliance or potential complications, such as in children with a history of rheumatic fever. The disadvantages of intramuscular penicillin are pain and allergic reactions. Bicillin C-R, containing procaine and benzathine penicillin, is the preferred method of delivering intramuscular penicillin to children. Benzathine penicillin alone is recommended for adolescents and adults and is less painful if administered after reaching room temperature.

Macrolides are an effective alternative for children who are allergic to penicillin. Azithromycin has fewer gastrointestinal side effects than erythromycin and is given only once a day for 5 days, but is more costly. A first-generation cephalosporin provides an effective alternative in penicillinallergic patients. Other cephalosporins offer the advantage of a shorter course of therapy (see Table 64 -3). Cephalosporins have a wider range of microbial coverage and are more costly than penicillin, however, and are not recommended as the initial antibiotic for children with streptococcal pharyngitis.

About 15% of children remain symptomatic carriers of GABHS after receiving adequate antibiotic therapy. In general, it is not necessary to culture or treat these children repeatedly if they remain asymptomatic. Repeat cultures should be obtained in children with recurrent or persistent symptoms or in children with a past history of rheumatic fever. In selected patients, eradication of the GABHS pharyngeal carrier state should be strongly considered (Box 64-1). Oral clindamycin is the most effective therapy, but oral rifampin in combination with benzathine penicillin is an effective alternative (see Table 64 -3).

M. pneumoniae may cause pharyngitis without pneumonia, but the diagnosis is difficult to make. If symptoms are persistent in children with suspected M. pneumoniae pharyngitis, treatment with any of the macrolide antibiotics (erythromycin, clarithromycin, or azithromycin) may be helpful. The macrolides also are a good choice for children with A. haemolyticum pharyngitis. Although rare in countries in which most children are vaccinated, Corynebacterium diphtheriae still may occur in less advantaged countries. Penicillin G and diphtheria antitoxin are used to treat this illness. Tularemia is an unusual cause of pharyngitis. If it is suspected, the treatment is with gentamicin.

Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for N. gonorrhoeae pharyngitis. Additional antibiotic coverage for C. trachomatis infection should be administered (see Table 64 -3). Other sites of gonococcal disease and sexual abuse should be considered in all children with gonococcal pharyngitis. Appropriate laboratory tests should be obtained to evaluate for other sexually transmitted diseases (see Chapter 224).

The management of peritonsillar space infection is controversial, and it should be managed in consultation with an otolaryngologist. If the patient has peritonsillar cellulitis, is non-toxic appearing, and does not have severe trismus or airway compromise, medical management is indicated. Younger children should receive intravenous penicillin, and older children and adolescents should receive oral penicillin. If the child improves within 12 to 24 hours, the diagnosis of peritonsillar cellulitis is confirmed, and surgical intervention is not needed. In one study of 38 children 8 months to 6 years old treated with intravenous penicillin for "peritonsillar abscess," 70% were discharged without an operative procedure.

Children with peritonsillar abscess who are toxic appearing, have severe trismus, or have airway compromise require a surgical intervention. In most cases, needle aspiration of the abscess is the procedure of choice and results in resolution in about 90% of cases. Often, especially in older children and adolescents, the needle aspiration may be performed in an outpatient setting with appropriate analgesia and sedation. In younger children, general anesthesia may be needed. In other cases, especially with recurrent tonsillitis or failed needle aspiration, incision and drainage or an abscess tonsillectomy may be preferred by the otolaryngologist. All of these patients should be started on penicillin (intravenous or oral) and should complete a 10-day course.

Children with either retropharyngeal or lateral pharyngeal abscesses require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics and probable surgical management. If CT does not show an obvious abscess or if the abscess appears small, medical management with intravenous antibiotics alone may suffice. Clindamycin alone or in combination with cefuroxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, or a third-generation cephalosporin and a penicillinase-resistant penicillin are suitable antibiotic choices. If the child is toxic appearing, there is airway compromise, or the abscess is large, surgical drainage is required. Most otolaryngologists prefer intraoral incision and drainage, but some achieve similar success rates with needle aspiration.

Management of croup and epiglottitis are discussed in Chapter 111 and on the CD-ROM. All pharyngeal tumors should be managed by an otolaryngologist. Biopsy or complete surgical removal usually is indicated. If the tumor is malignant or is potentially malignant, an oncologist should be involved early in the course of therapy. Children with a unilaterally enlarged tonsil should be referred for biopsy according to the guidelines listed in Box 64-2.

Adenotonsillar hypertrophy causing obstructive sleep apnea is a definite indication for adenotonsillectomy, although obstructive sleep disorders may be treated medically in some cases (see the CD-ROM and Chapter 251).

Minor trauma to the pharynx may be managed by the generalist. Significant trauma to the pharynx should be managed in consultation with an otolaryngologist. Any trauma to the pharynx causing respiratory distress or airway compromise may require endotracheal intubation or surgical management to secure the airway. Antibiotics are indicated for most significant pharyngeal injuries. Tetanus prophylaxis should be administered for all pharyngeal injuries depending on the child's immunization status. Pharyngeal lacerations or avulsions need to be evaluated carefully for their extent and may require imaging studies, laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and esophagoscopy. Caustic injuries to the pharynx require direct laryngoscopy and esophagoscopy. Esophagoscopy is indicated in almost all caustic ingestions because 8% to 20% of patients with esophageal burns have no evidence of oropharyngeal involvement. Conversely, esophageal burns may not be present even if the child has oropharyngeal burns. Thermal trauma often causes edema of the pharynx and airway compromise and may require subsequent laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and esophagoscopy.

The outcome of pharyngeal disorders depends on the cause of the disorder. Children with viral pharyngitis, because it is a self-limited illness, usually do well as long as pain is controlled and hydration is maintained. The rare pharyngeal complications of viral pharyngitis (i.e., peritonsillar abscess and airway obstruction) are associated with EBV infection. Children with bacterial pharyngitis, most commonly GABHS infection, also have an excellent outcome. The suppurative and nonsuppurative complications of bacterial pharyngitis usually are related to delayed diagnosis and treatment (i.e., peritonsillar abscess, rheumatic fever).

The outcome for deep neck abscesses is usually good, provided that the diagnosis is made early, antibiotics are started, and necessary surgical procedures are performed in a timely manner. Complications of deep neck abscesses include airway obstruction, rupture of the abscess into the airway, sepsis, mediastinitis, jugular vein thrombosis, cranial nerve palsies, and carotid artery rupture. Adverse outcome, including mortality, depends on the resolution of the complications.

Epiglottitis almost always has a good outcome if the airway is controlled and antibiotics are started early. If an airway is secured, pulmonary edema is the most common complication, occurring in about 9% of patients in one study. Extraepiglottic complications, such as pneumonia and cervical adenitis, occur commonly, whereas meningitis is rare. Adverse outcome, including hypoxic central nervous system injury and mortality, almost always can be prevented with early establishment of an airway.

The outcome for benign pharyngeal tumors is usually excellent. The outcome of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas is generally good if complete surgical removal is successful. Most complications are related to the inability to remove the tumor completely because of anatomic locations or to the surgery itself. Complications of malignant tumors usually relate to the anatomic structures involved and to the surgery. The outcome in children with pharyngeal malignant tumors depends on the type of tumor and its associated morbidity and mortality.

Accidental trauma to the pharynx usually is minor, and the outcome is excellent. Adverse outcomes may occur owing to complications associated with the injury if the trauma is to the lateral soft palate, peritonsillar area, or posterior pharynx. These areas are near vital structures, such as the carotid artery, which can become contused with potential subsequent thrombosis. Edema or hematomas from trauma may lead to respiratory compromise. Penetrating trauma from guns or knives often is associated with a bad outcome. The outcome from burns or chemicals is related to the extent of the trauma.

Most children with obstructive sleep disorders with adenotonsillar hypertrophy undergo successful adenotonsillectomy. Bleeding is the most concerning complication. Severe pain and persistent vomiting also may occur with an associated decrease in oral fluid intake and subsequent dehydration. Snoring and apnea sometimes continue after adenotonsillectomy. Other surgical and nonsurgical forms of therapy are beneficial to many patients with persistent symptoms. Tracheostomy rarely is needed for the child who is not responsive to other forms of treatment.

Children with viral pharyngitis and bacterial pharyngitis rarely need follow-up because these are self-limited diseases. If EBV is the cause of the pharyngitis, good anticipatory guidance regarding airway obstruction should be provided. If a child with EBV pharyngitis has evidence of early airway obstruction or is hospitalized for airway obstruction, close follow-up should be arranged. Children with recurrent bacterial tonsillitis should return for followup. Parents should be instructed to return for follow-up if, after 48 hours of antibiotic treatment, the child continues to have severe pain, difficulty swallowing, drooling, or a fever equal to or greater than 38.3°C.

The child treated for a deep neck abscess, epiglottitis, or penetrating trauma should be followed by an otolaryngolo-gist in conjunction with a generalist. Children with minor trauma to the pharynx can be followed as needed. Children with burns or chemical injuries should be followed according to the severity of the injury by the generalist and an otolaryngologist or gastroenterologist or both. Pharyngeal tumors should be followed by an otolaryngologist. If the tumor is malignant, an oncologist also should be involved in follow-up care.

Complete resolution of symptoms is typical in patients with obstructive sleep apnea after adenotonsillectomy. If symptoms persist, postoperative polysomnography should be obtained. Postoperative sleep studies also should be obtained in children with severe preoperative obstructive sleep apnea and in children with craniofacial anomalies or neurologic deficit. These high-risk patients are more likely to have recurrences and require more frequent and longer term follow-up.
